Unexpected Findings From Sitemap Planning

What planning before building actually saves you

!

Sitemap in 37 seconds vs 3 hours of whiteboard pain

Design agency used to whiteboard sitemaps for 3+ hours per client. Team arguing about pages, structure, navigation flow. Client changes mind halfway through. Everyone frustrated. Relume AI: prompt "marketing agency for B2B SaaS companies" ‚Üí 18-page sitemap in 37 seconds. Team spent 15 minutes tweaking instead of 3 hours debating. Client approved first version. 12x faster planning, zero drama.

!

Export to Framer: seamless handoff, zero rebuild

Founder planned 23-page SaaS site in Relume: sitemap generated in 30 seconds, wireframes in 4 minutes. Exported to Framer ‚Üí every page created automatically, components ready to customize, navigation linked, just add content. Total build time: 2 hours. Same project without planning: 8 hours total, including 3 hours of rebuilds due to structural changes discovered mid-build.

!

Free tier: 3 projects is enough for most freelancers

Freelance designer uses Relume free tier exclusively. 3 projects limit: she plans one project at a time. Workflow: Plan in Relume (free), export to Webflow, build site, get paid, archive Relume project, start next one. Never hits limit because she doesn't need active projects sitting around. Free tier = free forever for her workflow. She's saved $720/year (paid plan is $60/mo).

!

Component library: massive time saver for non-designers

Startup founder isn't a designer. Used to spend hours on navbars, footers, hero sections, pricing tables‚Äîalways looked amateur. Relume's component library: 1,000+ professional components, just swap content. Picked navbar style, swapped logo and links. Chose hero section, updated headline and CTA. Site looks like $10K agency build. Actual cost: $0 (free tier). Clients ask "which agency did you hire?"

!

Style guide generator: brand consistency automated

Relume generated complete style guide in seconds: colors (primary, secondary, accent), typography (headings, body, buttons), spacing system, button styles, form inputs, cards. Export to Framer ‚Üí all styles applied automatically across every page. No inconsistent branding. No client asking "why does this page look different?" Every page cohesive from day one. Zero manual styling required.

!

Client approvals: 2x faster with visual planning

Agency tracked 50 client projects. Projects with Relume planning: average 2 revision rounds before approval. Projects without planning: 4 revision rounds. Why? Clients can SEE the structure before building. No "I didn't know there would be a blog" or "where's the testimonial section?" Visual sitemap = clear expectations = fewer revisions = faster payment.

My Experience

The 4-Minute Wireframe That Saved a $12,000 Project

October 2024. Client‚ÄîAlex‚Äîfintech startup founder. Needed a 27-page website. Budget: $12,000. Timeline: 3 weeks.

Old workflow: Start building in Framer. Discover structural issues halfway through. Rebuild. Repeat. This usually took 4+ weeks on projects this size.

This time, I opened Relume first.

The prompt: "Fintech startup for Gen Z investors. Needs: homepage, product features, pricing, about, blog (5 posts), FAQ, contact, press kit, investor portal, help center, 3 case studies, comparison page vs competitors, careers, legal pages."

37 seconds later: Complete sitemap with 27 pages. Hierarchical structure. Navigation flow planned. Page relationships mapped.

4 minutes later: Every page wireframed. Hero sections, content blocks, CTAs positioned. Navigation structure visualized. Mobile responsiveness planned.

I shared with Alex: "Here's your site structure. Anything you want to change?"

Alex's feedback: "Move careers to footer. Add testimonials to pricing. Split help center into categories."

5 minutes later: Changes applied. Alex approved structure. Exported to Framer. Every page created automatically. Components ready. Just add content.

Total planning time: 15 minutes including client feedback loop.

Build time: 10 days instead of 4 weeks.

Delivered on time. Client paid $12,000 on schedule. No scope creep. No structural rebuilds. No stress.

Without Relume? This project would've taken 4-5 weeks with at least 2 major structural rebuilds. Would've missed deadline. Would've lost the client or had to discount. Planning first saved the project.

AI generates page layouts with sections, components, content blocks. See exactly what each page looks like before building. Export as starting point for Framer or Webflow.

Perfect for: Visualizing structure, client approvals, planning content

How Relume Fits Your Workflow

üéØ For Designers: Relume ‚Üí Framer Pipeline

Plan site structure in Relume (5 minutes). Export to Framer. Every page created automatically. Components ready to customize. Add your design flair. Launch in hours, not days. This is the modern designer workflow‚ÄîRelume plans, Framer builds. No more starting from blank canvas.

üíº For Agencies: Client Approval First, Build Later

Show clients sitemap and wireframes BEFORE building. Get structure approved. Eliminate "I didn't know there would be a blog" surprises. Export to Webflow once approved. Build with confidence. Fewer revisions, faster payments, happier clients.

üöÄ For Founders: Plan Your Vision, Hand Off to Developers

You know what you want. Plan it in Relume. Export sitemap and wireframes as specs. Hand to developer‚Äîthey know exactly what to build. No miscommunication. No "that's not what I wanted." Clear specs = right build, first time.

üìù For Content Teams: Structure First, Content Second

See every page before writing. Know what content goes where. Plan content gaps ("we need testimonials for pricing page"). Export structure, writers fill content, designers add visuals. No content written for pages that get cut. No rewriting because structure changed.

üí° Pro tip: Free tier is permanently free

Unlike other tools, Relume's free tier doesn't expire. Use it for 3 projects, archive old ones, continue planning forever. Perfect for freelancers who work sequentially.

‚úÖ Relume is Worth It If...

  • ‚Ä¢ You build websites for clients (agencies, freelancers)
  • ‚Ä¢ You work with Framer or Webflow
  • ‚Ä¢ You need client approvals before building
  • ‚Ä¢ You're planning complex sites (20+ pages)
  • ‚Ä¢ You want to avoid structural rebuilds
  • ‚Ä¢ You work in teams and need clear specs

‚ùå Skip Relume If...

  • ‚Ä¢ You only need simple one-page sites
  • ‚Ä¢ You don't use Framer or Webflow
  • ‚Ä¢ You enjoy planning as you build
  • ‚Ä¢ You never work with clients
  • ‚Ä¢ You're building a personal blog
  • ‚Ä¢ You don't care about structure

The Brutal Truth About Relume

!

It's a planning tool, not a builder

Relume doesn't build websites. It plans them. You'll need Framer, Webflow, or code to actually build. Don't expect to publish from Relume. Expect to plan, export, then build elsewhere. If you want all-in-one, use Durable or 10Web.

!

Free tier limitation: 3 active projects

Free tier caps at 3 projects. Hit the limit? Archive old projects to make room. Or upgrade to Pro ($20/mo). For most freelancers, 3 projects is plenty if you archive after completion. Agencies will hit the limit fast.

!

Wireframes are functional, not beautiful

Relume wireframes show structure, not design. Gray boxes, placeholder text, basic shapes. They're planning tools, not portfolio pieces. Don't show wireframes to clients as "your final design." Show them as "your site structure."

!

Export is great, but not magic

Export to Framer creates pages and components, but you still need to add content, customize design, make it yours. Export gives you 60% head start, not 100% done site. Plan for 40% work after export.

!

Learning curve for non-designers

If you don't know sitemaps, wireframes, component libraries‚ÄîRelume has a learning curve. Non-designers might find concepts foreign. Budget 30-60 minutes learning basics: what wireframes show, how sitemaps work, component reusability.

Bottom line: Relume is the best planning tool for website designers and agencies. Not a builder, not for everyone. But if you plan complex sites for clients? It'll save you hours and prevent disasters.
